case_data.summary:
This case is about the State of Vermont's Climate Superfund Act (State Act) which aims to hold fossil fuel businesses liable for climate change adaptation projects. The State Act imposes retroactive, strict liability on companies that have extracted or refined over one billion metric tons of greenhouse gases worldwide. 

On May 1, 2025, the United States filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Vermont. The Plaintiffs, the United States and the Environmental Protection Agency, sued the State of Vermont, Governor Philip Scott, the Secretary of the Vermont Agency of Natural Resources, and the Director of the Vermont Agency of Natural Resources Climate Action Office (Defendants). The Trump Administration alleged that the Clean Air Act preempted the State Act, infringed on the federal government's exclusive authority over interstate and foreign commerce, and encroached on the federal government's role in foreign affairs. Judge Mary Kay Lanthier was assigned to the case. 

The Plaintiffs alleged that the State Act attempted to usurp federal power by regulating national and global greenhouse gas emissions. Plaintiffs argued that the Clean Air Act preempted the State Act, exceeded Vermont's territorial reach, and interfered with the federal government's exclusive authority over interstate and foreign commerce and foreign affairs. To support these claims, the complaint emphasized that the Clean Air Act established a comprehensive framework for regulating air pollution, delegating authority to the EPA to set nationwide standards for greenhouse gases. The Plaintiffs further underscored the federal government's active role in international climate change initiatives, such as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, as evidence that foreign affairs powers were reserved exclusively to the federal government.

On July 9, 2025, the Northeast Organic Farming Association of Vermont and the Conservation Law Foundation filed a motion for permissive intervention, seeking to join the case as Defendants. The motion noted that a similar motion had been granted in a companion case, Chamber of Commerce v. Moore, which also challenged the State Act. On August 8, 2025, the motion to intervene was granted by Judge Lanthier.

On August 15, 2025, Vermont and associated heads of state agencies filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and failure to state a claim. On August 22, 2025, Northeast Organic Farming Association filed a similar motion.

On September 15, 2025, Defendants filed a motion for summary judgment. In addition to requesting the court grant the motion, Plaintiffs also asked the court to declare the State Act unconstitutional and permanently enjoin Defendants from taking any actions to implement the State Act.

This case is ongoing.

This case is about Vermontโs Climate Superfund Act, a law that makes big fossil fuel companies pay for projects to help the state handle climate change. The law says companies that have released more than a billion metric tons of greenhouse gases worldwide should help pay for fixing the damage.

On May 1, 2025, the United States and the Environmental Protection Agency took Vermont and its leaders to court. They said that Vermontโs law should not be allowed because only the federal government, not states, can make rules about pollution that affects the whole country or other countries. They talked about the Clean Air Act, a federal law that lets the EPA set pollution rules for the entire country, and said that Vermontโs law goes too far.

Later, two organizations, the Northeast Organic Farming Association of Vermont and the Conservation Law Foundation, joined the case to help defend the Vermont law. Vermont and the new groups asked the judge to dismiss the case. In September, the United States and Environmental Protection Agency filed a motion for summary judgment, asking the judge to say Vermontโs law is unconstitutional and should not be enforced. The case is still going on.

COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
Plaintiffs United States of America and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency bring this 
civil action against Defendants and allege as follows: 
INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The United States is facing an energy crisis. Overly restrictive policies and 
regulation have caused inadequate development of Americaโs abundant energy resources. Yet 
โ[a]n affordable and reliable domestic energy supply is essential to the national and economic 
security of the United States, as well as our foreign policy.โ Protecting American Energy From 
State Overreach, Exec. Order No. 14260, ยง 1, 90 Fed. Reg. 15,513 (Apr. 8, 2025).  
2.  As a result, on January 20, 2025, President Trump declared an energy emergency, 
concluding that the United Statesโ โinsufficient energy production, transportation, refining, and 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 2 of 28
 
generation constitutes an unusual and extraordinary threat to our Nationโs economy, national 
security, and foreign policy.โ Declaring a National Energy Emergency, Exec. Order 14156, ยง 1, 
90 Fed. Reg. 8,433 (Jan. 20, 2025).  
3.  These problems are โmost pronounced in our Nationโs Northeast and West Coast, 
where dangerous State and local policies jeopardize our Nationโs core national defense and 
security needs, and devastate the prosperity of not only local residents but the entire United 
States population.โ Id. Because of state restrictions and burdens on energy production, the 
American people are paying more for energy, and the United States is less able to defend itself 
from hostile foreign actors. Id. 
4.  At a time when States should be contributing to a national effort to secure reliable 
sources of domestic energy, Vermont has chosen to stand in the way. In May 2024, Vermont 
enacted its so-called โClimate Superfund Act,โ S.259, VT. STAT. ANN. tit. 10, ยงยง 596-599c, 
8003(33) (2024) (the โSuperfund Actโ). Vermontโs Superfund Act imposes retroactive strict 
liability and extraordinary monetary penalties on businesses that extracted and refined fossil 
fuels worldwide during the period from 1995 through 2024. VT. STAT. ANN. tit. 10, ยง 596(8), 
(22); id. ยง 598(a)(1). By purporting to regulate the effect of greenhouse gas emissions on climate 
change, the Act necessarily reaches far beyond the State of Vermont. The Superfund Act 
purports to regulate nationwide airspace and indeed the entire globe.   
5.  The Superfund Act is a transparent monetary-extraction scheme.  On its face, the 
statute purports to build a multibillion-dollar nest egg to fund โclimate change adaptation 
projectsโ within the State, paid for by out-of-state businesses. And this cost will not be borne 
solely by the out-of-state entities subject to the Superfund Act but also by ordinary Americans 
from coast to coast, individuals around the world, and in part directly by the United States 
2 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 3 of 28
 
Treasury, which receives royalties from oil leases overseen by the Department of the Interior and 
the Bureau of Land Management. 
6.  Vermontโs Superfund Act attempts to usurp the power of the federal government 
by regulating national and global emissions of greenhouse gases, violating federal law in 
multiple ways. See City of New York v. Chevron Corp., 993 F.3d 81, 92 (2d Cir. 2021) (holding 
that the regulation of global greenhouse gas emissions โis simply beyond the limits of state 
lawโ). The Superfund Act is preempted by the Clean Air Act, exceeds the territorial reach of 
Vermontโs legislative power, unlawfully discriminates against interstate commerce, conflicts 
with federal interstate commerce power, and is preempted by federal foreign-affairs powers.   
7.  The Superfund Act is a brazen attempt to grab power from the federal government 
and force citizens of other States and nations to foot the bill for Vermontโs infrastructure wish 
list. Along the way, the Superfund Act intrudes on, and interferes with, the federal governmentโs 
exclusive role in foreign affairs, which includes sensitive policy questions encompassing 
environmental concerns, economic and trade policies, and national security. This Nationโs 
Constitution and laws do not tolerate this interference. 
JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
 
8.  This Court has jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331 and 1345. 
9.  This Court has authority to provide the relief requested under the U.S. 
Constitution, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1651, 2201, and 2202, and its inherent legal and equitable powers. 
10.  The United States has standing to vindicate its sovereign, proprietary, and parens 
patriae interests. E.g., Arizona v. United States, 567 U.S. 387 (2012). The United Statesโ 
sovereign interests include ensuring that State laws like the Superfund Act do not interfere with 
federal law, including the Clean Air Act, or with the federal governmentโs exclusive authority 
3 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 4 of 28
 
over interstate and foreign commerce, greenhouse gas regulation, and national energy policy. 
The United Statesโ proprietary interests include its economic interests in revenue from fossil fuel 
leasing on federal lands, which generated over $13.8 billion in 2024,1 and its costs for 
purchasing fossil fuels, which will increase due to the Superfund Actโs recovery demand. See 
City of New York, 993 F.3d at 103 (observing that holding fossil fuel producers โaccountable for 
purely foreign activity (especially the Foreign Producers) would require them to internalize the 
costs of climate change and would presumably affect the price and production of fossil fuels 
abroad.โ). Additionally, the United States has parens patriae standing to protect the economic 
well-being of its citizens and the national energy market from the Actโs extraterritorial and 
excessive burdens, which will raise energy costs for consumers nationwide and disrupt the 
uniform regulation of fossil fuel production. These harms affect a substantial segment of the 
population, and individual litigants, such as fossil fuel businesses, cannot fully address the 
nationwide economic and constitutional injuries caused by the Actโs overreach. 
11.  This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendants because they reside in, or 
conduct a substantial portion of their official business in, Vermont. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 4(k)(1). 
12.  Venue is proper in the District of Vermont pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391, because 
at least one Defendant resides in the District and because a substantial part of the acts giving rise 
to this suit occurred within the District. 
 
 
 
 
1 The Department of the Interior manages land owned by the United States. The Department 
issues leases to produce fossil fuels from federal lands and for production in areas of the Outer 
Continental Shelf. Each year, the Department collects substantial revenue from those onshore 
and offshore leases. In 2024, the Department collected revenue of more than $490 million for 
coal, $950 million for gas, and $12.4 billion for oil. See U.S. DEPโT OF THE INTERIOR, NATURAL 
RESOURCES REVENUE DATA, https://revenuedata.doi.gov/ (last visited Apr. 30, 2025).

PARTIES 
 
13.  Plaintiff is the United States of America, suing on its own behalf, on behalf of its 
citizens, and on behalf of its executive departments and other subdivisions, including those listed 
below. 
14.  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is a federal executive agency 
with responsibility for administering the Clean Air Act, including decisions involving the 
regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, and implementing national environmental policies while 
considering economic growth, trade, and energy implications. 
15.  Defendant State of Vermont is a State of the United States. 
16.  Defendant Philip Scott is the Governor of the State of Vermont. He is sued in his 
official capacity. 
17.  Defendant Julie Moore is the Secretary of the Vermont Agency of Natural 
Resources. She is sued in her official capacity. Vermontโs Superfund Act requires Secretary 
Moore to issue cost recovery demands to certain energy producers and authorizes her to enforce 
the Actโs Climate Superfund Cost Recovery Program. VT. STAT. ANN. tit. 10, ยง 598(f), (g)(1), 
8003(a)(33). 
18.  Defendant Jane Lazorchak is the Director of the Vermont Agency of Natural 
Resources Climate Action Office. She is sued in her official capacity. Director Lazorchak is 
responsible for administering the Actโs Climate Superfund Cost Recovery Program. Id. ยง 597. 
ALLEGATIONS AND APPLICABLE LAW 
 
Vermontโs Climate Superfund Act 
 
19.  Vermontโs Climate Superfund Act seeks to impose retroactive fines or penalties 
on major American fossil fuel businesses for what Vermont alleges are the businessesโ purported 
5 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 6 of 28
 
contribution to greenhouse gas emissions. The Superfund Act then funnels those penalty dollars 
into a fund to subsidize various โclimate change adaptation projects.โ Id. ยงยง 597(1), 598(a)(1). 
20.  The Act applies to โ[r]esponsible parties,โ which is defined as โany entity or a 
successor in interest to an entity that during any part of the covered period was engaged in the 
trade or business of extracting fossil fuel or refining crude oil and is determined by the Agency 
attributable to for more than one billion metric tons of covered greenhouse gas emissions during 
the covered period.โ Id. ยง 596(22). 
21.  Vermontโs Superfund Act thus singles out a subset of entities that (1) extract 
fossil fuel, which is defined as โcoal, petroleum products, and fuel gases,โ or (2) refine oil. See 
id. ยง 596(12). 
22.  Among the entities subject to the Act are โforeign nation[s] . . . that hold[] or held 
an ownership interest in a fossil fuel businessโ from 1995 through 2024. Id. ยง 596(10). 
23.  The Act excludes downstream users of fossil fuels and entities that lack 
โsufficient connection with the State to satisfy the nexus requirements of the U.S. Constitution.โ 
Id. ยง 596(22). 
24.  The Act declares responsible parties strictly liable for their purported indirect 
contribution to global greenhouse gas emissions. Id. ยง 598(a)(1); see also id. ยง 596(7) 
(โโCovered greenhouse gas emissionsโ means the total quantity of greenhouse gases released into 
the atmosphere during the covered period, expressed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent, 
resulting from the use of fossil fuels extracted or refined by an entity.โ), (16) (defining 
โ[g]reenhouse gasโ by reference to section 552(11)); id. ยง 552(11) (defining โgreenhouse gasโ as 
โany chemical or physical substance that is emitted into the air and that the Secretary may 
6 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 7 of 28
 
reasonably anticipate to cause or contribute to climate change, including carbon dioxide, 
methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluorideโ). 
25.  The Act would therefore โregulate . . . behavior far beyond [Vermontโs] borders.โ 
City of New York, 993 F.3d at 92. Vermont โdoes not seek to hold [fossil fuel businesses] liable 
for the effects of emissions released in [Vermont], or even in [Vermontโs] neighboring states. 
Instead, [Vermont] intends to hold [fossil fuel businesses] liable, under [Vermont] law, for the 
effects of emissions made around the globe . . . .โ Id. 
26.  As a result of this new strict liability scheme, each responsible party will be 
required to pay a substantial โcost recovery demandโโeffectively a retroactive penalty or fine

Vermont could fund its โclimate change adaptation projectsโ through general taxation, such as 
state income or sales taxes, or by seeking federal grants, which are commonly used to support 
climate-related infrastructure without burdening interstate commerce. These alternatives would 
achieve Vermontโs goals without imposing a discriminatory multibillion-dollar cost recovery 
demand on out-of-state fossil fuel businesses, rendering the Superfund Actโs discriminatory 
approach unconstitutional. 
80.  Moreover, even if Vermontโs Superfund Act did not facially discriminate against 
interstate commerce and did not have non-discriminatory alternatives, it would still violate the 
Interstate Commerce Clause under the balancing test articulated in Pike v. Bruce Church, Inc., 
397 U.S. 137, 142 (1970). Under Pike, a state law that regulates evenhandedly and has only 
incidental effects on interstate commerce is unconstitutional if the burden imposed on interstate 
commerce is โclearly excessive in relation to the putative local benefits.โ Id. 
21 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 22 of 28
 
81.  Vermontโs Superfund Act purports to serve a legitimate local public interest by 
raising money to fund infrastructure projects allegedly necessitated by climate change. 
Regardless of whether environmental protection and infrastructure development are valid state 
objectives, the benefits of the Act are localized to Vermont and speculative, as the Actโs focus on 
retroactive liability for global greenhouse gas emissions does not directly address current or 
future environmental challenges within the State. 
82.  The Superfund Act also imposes substantial burdens on interstate commerce. By 
targeting fossil fuel businesses for extraction and refining activities occurring primarily in other 
States and foreign countries, the Act disrupts the national market for fossil fuels. The 
multibillion-dollar cost recovery demand will increase energy costs for consumers and 
businesses nationwide, as these costs are passed through the interstate energy market. And the 
Actโs retroactive penalties for lawful conduct from 1995 to 2024 discourage investment and 
innovation in the fossil fuel industry, further burdening interstate commerce. The potential for 
other States to adopt similar laws creates a risk of regulatory fragmentation, undermining the 
uniform national energy market. 
83.  Vermontโs Superfund Act imposes a substantial and undue burden on interstate 
commerce that is clearly excessive in relation to any putative local benefits. 
84.  Vermont seeks to hold the largest American fossil fuel businesses liable for their 
extraction and refining activities which, upon information and belief, occur almost exclusively in 
States other than Vermont. Vermontโs Superfund Act imposes billions of dollars in aggregate 
liability on those fossil fuel businesses. The Act will raise the cost of energy resources transacted 
in interstate commerce. 
85.  Thus, Vermontโs Superfund Act violates the Interstate Commerce Clause.   
22 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 23 of 28
 
COUNT IV 
Violation of the Foreign Commerce Clause 
 
86.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated above. 
87.  The Constitution provides that โ[t]his Constitution, and the Laws of the United 
States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, 
under the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land; . . . any Thing in 
the Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding.โ  U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 
2. 
88.  The Constitution gives Congress the โPower . . . [t]o regulate Commerce with 
foreign Nations . . . .โ  U.S. Const. art. I, ยง 8, cl. 3. 
89.  The Foreign Commerce Clause has a negative application. Thus, for example, 
State laws that impose taxes on foreign commerce โwill not survive Commerce Clause scrutiny if 
the taxpayer demonstrates that the taxโ implicates one of the four concerns identified in 
Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 U.S. 274, 279 (1977). See Barclays Bank PLC v. 
Franchise Tax Bd. of California, 512 U.S. 298, 310 (1994). A State law imposing taxes is 
unconstitutional if it (1) applies to an activity lacking a substantial nexus to the State; (2) is not 
fairly apportioned; (3) discriminates against interstate commerce; or (4) is not fairly related to 
the services provided by the State. See Barclays Bank PLC, 512 U.S. at 310-11 (citing Complete 
Auto, 430 U.S. at 279). โIn the unique context of foreign commerce, a Stateโs power is further 
constrained because of the special need for federal uniformity.โ Id. at 311 (cleaned up). Thus, 
โ[a] tax affecting foreign commerce therefore raises two concerns in addition to the four 
delineated in Complete Auto.โ Id. โThe first is prompted by the enhanced risk of multiple 
taxation. The second relates to the Federal Governmentโs capacity to speak with one voice when 
regulating commercial relations with foreign governments.โ Id. (cleaned up). 
23 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 24 of 28
 
90.  Vermontโs Superfund Act is not a state tax. But the same limiting principles that 
apply to a Stateโs power to impose taxes on foreign commerce also apply to a Stateโs power to 
impose penalties, fines, and other civil liability on foreign commerce. 
91.  Vermontโs Superfund Act discriminates against foreign commerce facially, in 
practical effect, and in purpose by imposing penalties or fines that directly and substantially 
burden foreign commerce. The Act imposes strict liability on fossil fuel businesses for 
activitiesโextraction and refining of fossil fuelsโthat occurred in foreign countries. The Act 
imposes liability on these foreign activities even though they lack a substantial nexus to 
Vermont. The Act does not fairly apportion liability based on commerce in Vermont. The Act 
also discriminates against foreign commerce and imposes liability that is not fairly related to the 
services provided by the State. The Act enhances the risk of multiple States imposing 
overlapping liability on foreign commerce for the same activities. And the Act harms the federal 
governmentโs capacity to speak with one voice when conducting commercial relations with 
foreign governments on issues such as regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, trade policy, 
exports and imports of fossil fuels, and national security.  
92.  The United States does not challenge Vermontโs authority to regulate the local 
activities of international corporations, such as emissions from in-state facilities or taxes on in-
state sales. Ordinary state regulations that incidentally affect foreign commerce without such 
extraterritorial scope or federal interference remain permissible under the Foreign Commerce 
Clause. But Vermontโs Superfund Act does not fall within this permissible role for States. 
Rather, the Act directly regulates worldwide fossil fuel extraction and refining with minimal 
nexus to Vermont, imposes a disproportionate burden on foreign commerce, and undermines the 
24 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 25 of 28
 
federal governmentโs ability to maintain uniformity in regulating environmental, trade, and 
national security policy. 
93.  Thus, Vermontโs Superfund Act violates the Foreign Commerce Clause. 
COUNT V 
Foreign Affairs Preemption 
 
94.  The United States incorporates by reference all allegations stated above. 
95.  The Constitution provides that โ[t]his Constitution, and the Laws of the United 
States which shall be made in Pursuance thereof; and all Treaties made, or which shall be made, 
under the Authority of the United States, shall be the supreme Law of the Land; . . . any Thing in 
the Constitution or Laws of any State to the Contrary notwithstanding.โ U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2. 
96.  Even aside from his military powers as the โCommander in Chief of the Army 
and Navy,โ id. art. II, ยง 2, cl. 1, the Constitution vests broad responsibility for the conduct of 
foreign affairs in the President of the United States. 
97.  The President has โPower, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Senate, to 
make Treaties, provided two thirds of the Senators present concur.โ Id. art. II, ยง2, cl. 2. 
98.  The President โnominate[s], and by and with the Advice and Consent of the 
Senate, . . . appoint[s] Ambassadors, other public Ministers and Consuls.โ Id. 
99.  The President โreceive[s] Ambassadors and other public Ministers.โ Id. art II, ยง 3. 
100.  The Constitution authorizes the President to โtake Care that the Laws be faithfully 
executed.โ Id. 
101.  In short, โthe supremacy of the national power in the general field of foreign 
affairs . . . is made clear by the Constitution.โ Hines, 312 U.S. at 62. 
102.  The Supreme Court has interpreted the provisions of the Constitution that vest 
authority over foreign affairs in the President to prohibit actions by the States that lie outside 
25 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 26 of 28
 
their traditional and localized areas of responsibility and instead interfere with the federal 
governmentโs foreign policy, or otherwise has more than an incidental effect in conflict with 
express foreign policy. See Garamendi, 539 U.S. at 418-20. 
103.  Vermontโs Superfund Act falls outside the area of any traditional state interest. It 
instead regulates โa uniquely international problemโ that is โnot well-suited to the application of 
state law.โ City of New York, 993 F.3d at 85-86. 
104.  By adopting the Framework Convention, the federal government undertook to 
formulate foreign policy with respect to the โstabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in 
the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the 
climate system.โ  Framework Convention, Art. 2. 
105.  Vermontโs Superfund Act imposes retroactive liability on fossil fuel businesses 
for their extraction or refining of fossil fuels worldwide. 
106.  By attempting to impose liability based on greenhouse gas emissions purportedly 
attributable to worldwide fossil fuel extraction and refining, Vermontโs Superfund Act could 
undermine the ability of the United States to speak with one voice on a matter of pressing 
interest around the globe. The Act also could complicate the United Statesโ relations with foreign 
countries concerning regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, trade policy, and exports and 
imports of fossil fuels. The Act also penalizes extraction and refining activities in foreign 
countries despite the Presidentโs explicit judgment that energy imports should be exempt from 
the tariffs imposed under Executive Order 14257. 
107.  Vermontโs Superfund Act interferes with the United Statesโ foreign policy on 
greenhouse gas regulation, including but not limited to the United Statesโ participation in the 
26 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 27 of 28
 
Framework Convention and announcement of its intention to withdraw from the Paris 
Agreement, and is therefore preempted. 
108.  This claim does not challenge Vermontโs authority to enact local regulations that 
incidentally affect international corporations, such as environmental standards for in-state 
operations. Instead, the United States seeks to invalidate Vermontโs Superfund Act because its 
imposition of retroactive liability for worldwide greenhouse gas emissions directly intrudes on 
the federal governmentโs exclusive authority over foreign affairs, including the United Nations 
Framework Convention on Climate Change and trade policy. This extraordinary extraterritorial 
reach and conflict with federal foreign policy distinguish the Act from ordinary state regulations 
that do not undermine the United Statesโ ability to speak with one voice in international relations. 
109.  Simply put, Vermontโs attempt โto recover damages for the harms caused by 
global greenhouse gas emissions mayโ not โproceed under [State] law.โ City of New York, 993 
F.3d at 91. 
110.  Thus, Vermontโs Superfund Act is preempted by the foreign affairs doctrine.   
27 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 1     Filed 05/01/25     Page 28 of 28
 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
 
WHEREFORE, the United States respectfully requests that this Court: 
A.  Declare Vermontโs Climate Superfund Act unconstitutional and unenforceable 
under 28 U.S.C. ยง 2201, both facially and as applied; 
B.  Permanently enjoin Defendants from taking actions to implement or enforce 
Vermontโs Climate Superfund Act; 
C.  Award the United States its costs and disbursements in this action; and 
D.  Award such other and further relief as the Court may deem just and proper.

PRELIMINARY STATEMENT  
Northeast Organic Farming Association of Vermont and Conservation Law Foundation 
hereby move for permissive intervention in the above-captioned proceeding pursuant to Federal 
Rule of Civil Procedure 24(b)(1)(B). Movants also seek leave to defer filing their responsive 
pleading pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(c) until August 22, 2025.  
Last week, this Court granted Movantsโ motion for permissive intervention in a 
companion case also involving a challenge to the Vermont Climate Superfund Act (the โActโ), 
Chamber of Commerce v. Moore (Case No. 2:24-cv-01513). This motion presents identical 
questions as that motionโquestions the Court considered and resolved in permitting Movants to 
intervene in the companion case. Both cases challenge the same statute, involve similar legal 
issues, seek similar relief against the same defendants, and will be briefed on the same schedule. 
Movants in both cases have a substantial interest in defending the Act. Movants seek to intervene 
in this case as well to clarify and ensure that Movants may be heard on all issues raised by 
Plaintiffs in both cases and fully participate in the briefing of those issues. Because the Court has 
already entered a briefing schedule that can accommodate Movantsโ participation, this timely 
motion will not require any changes to the existing briefing schedule or otherwise prejudice 
Plaintiffs.  
To avoid burdening the Court and Plaintiffs with potentially extraneous motion practice, 
Movants deferred filing this motion until after the Court ruled on their motion to intervene in 
Chamber. To avoid any surprise to Plaintiffs, on June 11 Movantsโ lawyers advised counsel for 
the United States of Movantsโ plan to defer filing their motion to intervene in this case. On June 
30, shortly after the Court granted the motion to intervene in the Chamber case, Movantsโ 
counsel again contacted counsel for the United States, seeking agreement to Movantsโ 
intervention in this matter. The United States, however, advised counsel that they oppose 
1 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 24     Filed 07/09/25     Page 5 of 11
intervention, necessitating the filing of this contested motion. Undersigned counsel have also 
spoken to counsel for Defendants, who represented that Defendants consent to the relief 
requested by this Motion. 
ARGUMENT 
Movants seek permissive intervention under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(b)(1)(B). 
A district court may grant permissive intervention โif the application is timely and if the 
โapplicantโs claim or defense and the main action have a question of law or fact in common.โโ In 
re Holocaust Victim Assets Litig., 225 F.3d 191, 202 (2d Cir. 2000) (citing Fed. R. Civ. P. 
24(b)(1)). The courtโs โprincipal guideโ in exercising its discretion is โwhether the intervention 
will unduly delay or prejudice the adjudication of the rights of the original parties.โ United States 
v. Pitney Bowes, Inc., 25 F.3d 66, 73 (2d Cir. 1994) (citing Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(3)). The court 
may also consider the โnature and extentโ of proposed intervenorsโ interests and whether they 
will โsignificantly contributeโ to, among other things, โthe just and equitable adjudication of the 
legal questions presented.โ H.L. Hayden Co. of N.Y. v. Siemens Med. Sys., Inc., 797 F.2d 85, 89 
(2d Cir. 1986). These considerations all support permissive intervention here.1 
I.  Movants merit permissive intervention  
A.  This timely motion will not cause undue delay or prejudice  
This motionโfiled less than two months after Plaintiffs served their complaint, ECF Nos. 
10, 11, 12, 13โis timely. The case is still in its early stages: initial briefing begins on August 15 
and extends through December. ECF No. 23; Bldg. & Realty Inst. of Westchester & Putnam 
Ctys., Inc. v. State of New York, No. 19-cv-11285 (KMK), 2020 WL 5658703, at *7 (S.D.N.Y. 
 
1 Movants need not establish Article III standing because as prospective defendant-intervenors, 
they do not seek to invoke the Courtโs jurisdiction. See Va. House of Delegates v. Bethune-Hill, 
587 U.S. 658, 663 (2019). 
2 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 24     Filed 07/09/25     Page 6 of 11
Sept. 23, 2020) (intervention motion filed three months after complaint was timely where case 
was in early stages and no significant substantive motions had been filed); Allco Fin. Ltd. v. Etsy, 
300 F.R.D. 83, 86 (D. Conn. 2014) (intervention motion filed three months after suit was timely 
where defendant had not answered or moved to dismiss). 
Movantsโ intervention will not cause undue delay or prejudice to the existing parties. See 
Order Granting Northeast Organic Farming Association of Vermont and Conservation Law 
Foundationโs Mot. to Intervene at 5, Chamber of Com. v. Moore, No. 2:24-cv-01513 (D. Vt. June 
30, 2025), ECF No. 49 (โChamber Orderโ). The schedules this Court has ordered in the two 
cases can accommodate Movantsโ participation. See ECF No. 23; Scheduling Order, Chamber of 
Com. v. Moore, No. 2:24-cv-01513 (D. Vt. June 30, 2025), ECF No. 52. In fact, the Chamber 
order already sets deadlines for Movants, and adding those deadlines to this case will not require 
changes to any other partiesโ deadlines or otherwise delay briefing. Movants are committed to 
avoiding duplication and working with the parties to advance the efficient adjudication of this 
matter. See Chamber Order at 5.  
B.  Movantsโ defense shares common questions of law with the main action 
Movants intend to address the fundamental legal questions presented by Plaintiffs by 
showing that the Climate Superfund Act is constitutional and is not preempted. Movantsโ defense 
thus shares common questions of law with the main action. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(1)(B); 
Chamber Order at 6. 
C.  Movants have strong interests in preserving the Act  
The โnature and extentโ of Movantsโ interests in this case weigh in favor of intervention. 
H.L. Hayden, 797 F.2d at 89. Movantsโ members have experienced or witnessed firsthand harms 
from climate change and will continue to face these harms without additionalโand costlyโ
3 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 24     Filed 07/09/25     Page 7 of 11
adaptation measures. These are precisely the harms that motivated the Actโs passage and which 
the Act seeks to limit in the future.  
  Movantsโ membersโ homes, businesses, and communities have been devastated by 
flooding. Declaration of Allison Palmer (Palmer Decl.) ยถยถ 3-8; Declaration of Karl Bissex 
(Bissex Decl.) ยถยถ 4-6; Declaration of Katie Trautz (Trautz Decl.) ยถ 7; Declaration of Wesley 
Hamilton (Hamilton Decl.) ยถยถ 3, 5; Declaration of Andy Jones (Jones Decl.) ยถยถ 9-10, Declaration 
of Grace Oedel (Oedel Decl.) ยถยถ 7, 9.2 Members have experienced and witnessed other climate 
impacts too, including heavier rainfall, increased drought, warmer summers, and wildfire smoke. 
Jones Decl. ยถยถ 14-15, Oedel Decl. ยถ 10, Declaration of Megan Malgeri (Malgeri Decl.) ยถยถ 4-8, 
Trautz Decl. ยถ 12. Movants and their members are currently shouldering the cost of recovering 
from these climate harms and adapting for the future: They have built floodwalls for their homes, 
gutted and rebuilt their businesses, moved their crops into greenhouses, begun the process of 
relocating their communities and businesses to higher ground, and more. Palmer Decl. ยถยถ 11-12; 
Bissex Decl. ยถยถ 15-16; Hamilton Decl. ยถยถ 5-7; Jones Decl. ยถ 8. 
Movants stand to benefit from the Act. Funds from the Act could be used for a wide range 
of additional adaptation projects to protect Movants and their members against future climate 
harms. Trautz Decl. ยถ 14; Hamilton Decl. ยถ 9; Bissex Decl. ยถ 15; Jones Decl. ยถยถ 17, 19; Oedel 
Decl. ยถ 14; Malgeri Decl. ยถ 10; Vt. Stat. Ann. tit. 10, ยง 596(2) (defining โclimate change adaption 
projectโ). In addition, Movants and their membersโhundreds of individuals and farmsโmay 
benefit from other public projects that may be eligible for funding under the Act, such as 
upgrades to stormwater systems, the electric grid, bridges, and other infrastructure. Because โthe 
 
2 Movants have attached the same declarations they and their members submitted in the Chamber 
case.  
4 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 24     Filed 07/09/25     Page 8 of 11
validity of a [law] from which its members benefit is challenged,โ Movants have a โsufficientโ 
interest in this case. N.Y. Pub. Int. Rsch. Grp., Inc. v. Regents of Univ. of State of N.Y., 516 F.2d 
350, 352 (2d Cir. 1975) (per curiam). 
Finally, Movants and their members played a critical role in advocating for the Act. CLF 
advised lawmakers during the legislative process and testified in support of the Act. Declaration 
of Kate Sinding Daly (Daly Decl.) ยถ 8. Andy Jones, a NOFA Vermont member, likewise testified 
in support of the Act. Jones Decl. ยถ 20. And CLF continues to track and support the Actโs 
implementation. Daly Decl. ยถ 9. Movants โhave an interest in seeking to uphold the validity of 
the legislation they worked to enactโ and โwould be denied the full opportunity to do so ifโ not 
permitted to intervene. Chamber Order at 6; see also Bldg. & Realty Inst., 2020 WL 5658703, at 
*11; Commack Self-Serv. Kosher Meats, Inc. v. Rubin, 170 F.R.D. 93, 102 (E.D.N.Y. 1996); 
Green Mountain Chrysler Plymouth Dodge Jeep v. Torti, No. 2:05-cv-302, 2006 WL 8567240, 
at *4 (D. Vt. May 3, 2006). 
D.  Movants will contribute to the just and equitable adjudication of the case 
Movants will โsignificantly contributeโ to โthe just and equitable adjudication of the legal 
questions presented.โ H.L. Hayden, 797 F.2d at 89. โ[B]y representing a cross-section of 
Vermont citizens who have been allegedly harmed by climate change, [Movants] bear a unique 
perspective which will allow for the full development of relevant facts.โ Chamber Order at 7; see 
also Commack, 170 F.R.D. at 106. And Movantsโ โviewpoint and knowledge of the underlying 
circumstances would assist the court during the course of litigation.โ Chamber Order at 8 (citing 
335-7 LLC v. City of New York, No. 20-cv-1053, 2020 WL 3100085, at *3 (S.D.N.Y June 11, 
2020)). 
5 
 

2:25-cv-00463-mkl     Document 24     Filed 07/09/25     Page 9 of 11
E.  Movants need not show that the Stateโs representation is inadequate 
  As the Court recognized in the companion case, Rule 24(b) does not necessitate โa 
finding that party representation be inadequateโ in order to grant permissive intervention. 
Chamber Order at 7 (quoting New York v. United States Depโt of Health & Hum. Servs., No. 19-
cv-4676 (PAE), 2019 WL 3531960, at *6 (S.D.N.Y. Aug. 2, 2019)). Accordingly, courts in this 
circuit routinely grant permissive intervention even when the state government will adequately 
defend the challenged law. See, e.g., New York, 2019 WL 3531960, at *6 (granting permissive 
intervention without a finding of inadequate representation); Comcast of Conn. v. Vt. Pub. Util. 
Commโn, No. 5:17-cv-161 (GWC), 2018 WL 11469513, at *4 (D. Vt. Feb. 8, 2018) (same); Vt.
